TextEquiv.Unicode: vanquished by concupiscence and sin,
For to this ende shoote al the exhorta
tions of the Prophets & Apostles, cal
ling on still to returne to the Lord.
Finally, the Lorde doth so forgive
our sinnes, that hee will never once re
memder them againe. For so he fore
teld us by Jere. in his 31. cha. He ther
fore doth not punish us. For hee hath
not onely forgiven the fault, but also
the punishment aue for the sin. Nowe
then, whereas the Lord sometime doth
whip us with his scourges, and whip
peth us for our sinnes indeede : as the
holie Scripture doth plainly declare,
hee doth it not to the intent, that with
our affliction wee shoulde make satis
faction for the sinnes wee have com
mitted: For then should the death of
Christ be of none effect: but the Lord
with whipping doeth chastise us, & by
whipping us doth let us understand,
that hee liketh not of the sinnes which
wee have committed, and hee doth free
ly forgive: By whipping us also he
maketh us exaples to otherr least they
sinne too, and cutteth from us all occa
sion of sinning, and by the Crosse doeth
keepe our patience in ure. This thus
farre, touching the forgivenes of sins,
Of which I have said somewhat in
my sermon of faith that justifieth: and
elsewhere.
The eleventh Article is this, The
resurrection of the fleshe. These two
Articles, this and the twelfth shutte
up as briefly as may bee, the most er
cellent fruit of faith, and summe of al
perfection, they wrap up I say, the end
of faith, in confessing life everlasting, &
the ful & perfect salvation of the whole
man. For ye whole ma shalbe saved, as
well in soule as bodie. For as man by
sinne did perish both in body and soule,
so ought he to be restored againe both
bodily and ghostly : and as hee ought

vanquished by concupiscence and sin, For to this ende shoote al the exhorta tions of the Prophets & Apostles, cal ling on still to returne to the Lord. Finally, the Lorde doth so forgive our sinnes, that hee will never once re memder them againe. For so he fore teld us by Jere. in his 31. cha. He ther fore doth not punish us. For hee hath not onely forgiven the fault, but also the punishment aue for the sin. Nowe then, whereas the Lord sometime doth whip us with his scourges, and whip peth us for our sinnes indeede : as the holie Scripture doth plainly declare, hee doth it not to the intent, that with our affliction wee shoulde make satis faction for the sinnes wee have com mitted: For then should the death of Christ be of none effect: but the Lord with whipping doeth chastise us, & by whipping us doth let us understand, that hee liketh not of the sinnes which wee have committed, and hee doth free ly forgive: By whipping us also he maketh us exaples to otherr least they sinne too, and cutteth from us all occa sion of sinning, and by the Crosse doeth keepe our patience in ure. This thus farre, touching the forgivenes of sins, Of which I have said somewhat in my sermon of faith that justifieth: and elsewhere. The eleventh Article is this, The resurrection of the fleshe. These two Articles, this and the twelfth shutte up as briefly as may bee, the most er cellent fruit of faith, and summe of al perfection, they wrap up I say, the end of faith, in confessing life everlasting, & the ful & perfect salvation of the whole man. For ye whole ma shalbe saved, as well in soule as bodie. For as man by sinne did perish both in body and soule, so ought he to be restored againe both bodily and ghostly : and as hee ought
so was hee by Christ restored againe
The soule of man verily is a spirite
and dieth not at allithe body is earthly
and therefore dieth and rotteth. For
which cause many holde opinion that
the bodies dye, never to be made par
takers of joy or payne in the worlde to
come. But we in this article professe
the contrary, acknowledging, ye those
our bodies, & so that flesh of ours shall
rise agayne, andenter into life everla
sting.
Of this word Resurrection or ri
sing againe, I have spoken in the ex
position of that article, The third day
he rose againe from the dead. But
nowe this worde fleshe doth a great
deale more significantly expresse the
resurrection of this fleshe, than if we
should say the resurrection of the body
Verily Cyprian sayth, that in some
churches of the East, this article was
thus pronounced: I befeeve the resur
reetion of this fleshe. And Augustine
also in the tenth chapter of his booke
De side G.mholo, sayth: wee must
without doubting beleeve, that this
visible, which is properly called flesh,
shall rise againe. The Apostle Paul
doth seeme, as it were, with his finger
to point at this flesh, when hee saithe
This corruptible must put on incor
ruption. when hee saieth: This, hee
doth, as it were, put out his finger un
to this flesh. This hath Augustine.
Moreover, Saynt Hierome compel
leth John, Bishoppe of Hierusalem
openly to confesse the resurrectiou of
the flesh, not of the bodie onely. Veshe
saith he, hath one definition, and the
bodie an other. All flesh is a bodyrbut
everie bodie is not feshe. That is
fleshe properly, which is compact of
bloud, veynes, bones, and synewes.
A bodie, although it be called fleshe,
yet sometimes is said to be of like sub

so was hee by Christ restored againe The soule of man verily is a spirite and dieth not at allithe body is earthly and therefore dieth and rotteth. For which cause many holde opinion that the bodies dye, never to be made par takers of joy or payne in the worlde to come. But we in this article professe the contrary, acknowledging, ye those our bodies, & so that flesh of ours shall rise agayne, andenter into life everla sting. Of this word Resurrection or ri sing againe, I have spoken in the ex position of that article, The third day he rose againe from the dead. But nowe this worde fleshe doth a great deale more significantly expresse the resurrection of this fleshe, than if we should say the resurrection of the body Verily Cyprian sayth, that in some churches of the East, this article was thus pronounced: I befeeve the resur reetion of this fleshe. And Augustine also in the tenth chapter of his booke De side G.mholo, sayth: wee must without doubting beleeve, that this visible, which is properly called flesh, shall rise againe. The Apostle Paul doth seeme, as it were, with his finger to point at this flesh, when hee saithe This corruptible must put on incor ruption. when hee saieth: This, hee doth, as it were, put out his finger un to this flesh. This hath Augustine. Moreover, Saynt Hierome compel leth John, Bishoppe of Hierusalem openly to confesse the resurrectiou of the flesh, not of the bodie onely. Veshe saith he, hath one definition, and the bodie an other. All flesh is a bodyrbut everie bodie is not feshe. That is fleshe properly, which is compact of bloud, veynes, bones, and synewes. A bodie, although it be called fleshe, yet sometimes is said to be of like sub
